subject: Re: [TEST] JTest v4.5 and what is says about JUnit
msgSnippet: Hello All, I also work for Parasoft in the sales organization, but I think I may be able to shed some light upon the subject.  Let me see if I can clarify a
messageBody:
Hello All,

I also work for Parasoft in the sales organization, but I think I may
be able to shed some light upon the subject. Let me see if I can
clarify a bit about the @pre tag. When Jtest automatically generates
test cases for a method, it will read this tag and not generate any
input which specifically violates the defined pre-condition. If an
@post tag is present, Jtest will try to generate inputs which would
adhere to the @pre condition, but intentionally try to break the
@post condition. If the @post condition were able to be violated,
this would indicate a serious flaw in the code.

Also, Jtest can report a @pre violation if the method with the @pre
tag is called by another method and that @pre condition is violated.
For example, let's say you have method A which calls method B.
Method B has some @pre defined and Jtest generates a test for method
A which calls method B in such a manner which violates method B's
@pre condition. Here, Jtest would report a @pre violation.

These particular features are related to DBC. The above is just a
small subset of what ParaSoft's tools can do in relation to DBC. If
you want more info on DBC, you can go to
http://www.parasoft.com/jsp/products/article.jsp?
articleId=579&product=Jcontract

Regards,
David McCaw



--- In junit@y..., Ilja Preuß <ilja.preuss@w...> wrote:
> What exactly does the @pre tag do? Does it test that the method
fails if called with an invalid value?
>
> > --- In junit@y..., "rxqch" <rxqch@y...> wrote:
> > > Hi, I work with parasoft tech support and the answer to the
> > question
> > > below is yes. One can use an @pre tag in javadoc to find such
> > > problems.
> > >
> > > Carson
> > >
> > > --- In junit@y..., Ilja Preuß <ilja.preuss@w...> wrote:
> > > > > The problem is that I don't know if there was a problem with
> > > > > the input, the processing or something random. If your code
> > > > > returns an IllegalArgumentException, then I have a much
> > > > > better idea of the issues.
> > > >
> > > > If you are on the same team, you could ask him. Possibly you
> > could
> > > even
> > > > find out by simply looking at the code and/or the JUnit tests.
> > > >
> > > > One point I find more critical is that invalid input should be
> > > > fail-fast. If a method fails because you provided invalid
input
> > to a
> > > > prior method call, such problems are really hard to find. Can
> > JTest
> > > help
> > > > with such issues?
> > > >
> > > > Regards, Ilja
> >
> >
> >
> >

http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/

>
